content:
Write Effective Broadcast Messages

Broadcast informative, useful messages to customers and employees in a standard SMS channel in Service Cloud.

Standard SMS channels are scheduled for retirement, and we’re limiting the ability to create standard channels. To avoid service interruptions, upgrade your standard SMS channels to enhanced channels before February 14, 2026.

Create Broadcast Messaging Templates
Write messages for broadcasters to send to recipients. Broadcasters can’t create templates or send a message without a template, so create as many templates as you think your team needs.

Mind the Character Limit
Text messages are limited to 160 characters for most carriers. Keep your message short to avoid paying for extra messages.

Stay On Topic
Your recipients opted in to your messages for a specific purpose. Avoid sending frequent, off-topic messages or sharing information that’s better suited for email.

Personalize Sparingly
It’s great to include your recipient’s name in a message here and there with a merge field. But too much personalization can be overwhelming, and it can use up your character count.

Use a Link Shortener
If you include links in your messages, use a link shortener to save space. Links count against the 160-character limit.

Include a Call to Action
A call to action makes your message more useful to recipients.

Examples of Broadcast SMS Messages

Send bulk updates to your customers when you have a widespread service-related announcement.
Send a text when the recipient joins the list, when they are at the top of the list, and when they remove themselves from the list.
Send confirmations and reminders for appointments.
Send updates to your hospitality guests so they know when there are changes in your facility.
Send updates about your school’s facilities to students and their families.
Communicate important information to your employees.
title: Effective Broadcast Messaging in Service Cloud
